data.text: Bikepacking Tents are Expensive. What Else Do You Recommend?

I know I'm always posting, but I'm trying to pick people's brains that have been bikepacking/touring for a while. What do you ask recommend in terms of tents? It seems some of the "bikepacking" tents might just be overpriced because they're specialized. What tents do you guys recommend? Preferably not breaking the bank, but I'm willing to hear about all of them. Preferably 2 person tent. Thanks!
Nature hike. 2 person tent not too expensive. Solid quality. Amazon prime day deals!

data.text:
I have the backpacking version of this tent, and I love how light and small it is. Sometimes I wish it had more headroom in it when waiting out a rain storm with another person. Overall, it is small, light weight, and weatherproof. I do think you get what you pay for when it comes to tents. https://www.bigagnes.com/Fly-Creek-HV-UL2-Bikepack
Fly Creek HV UL2 Bikepack

data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: was considering the big Agnes tiger wall ul2 bikepacking version. Just kind of expensive, not sure if it's worth it. I've heard about the fly creek several times. Considering that as well.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: fly creek is worth every penny
data.author: Dan Reilly

data.text: I have the more expensive lightweight version of the fly creek and it's great. The bike packing version in the link is a little heavier, shorter pole sections, and cheaper. The tiger wall is heavier, but I don't think that matters for bike packing. I like that it has two doors which is great when you're sharing a tent. It also has more headroom than the fly creek.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: I have the Fly Creek 2 and the Tiger Wall 2. They are both good. Fly Creek a little bit lighter, Tiger Wall a little bit more convenient with 2 people. If you are by yourself, you don't need 2 doors and 2 vestibules. But maybe you want to use it as well for camping with family or something. For bike travel I take the Fly Creek. Big Agnes quality is good.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: Also, with tents just like with many things, you get what you pay for. Big Agnes is a highly regarded brand. I've used a bunch of models from them and been happy so far.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: thanks for this comment. This helps. I'm likely gonna choose one of these.

data.text: got a fly creek also and have used it a lot, only thing I hate is the front entry - it makes getting in and out a huge hassle in rain, or with another person.

data.author: Tim Silvester

data.text: The 3FUL Lanshan pro tents are great. Very light, pack tiny & priced well. Hiking pole pitch but you can just use a single shock corded aluminium or carbon pole. I just bought a cheap replacement aluminium pole kit for a random tent from go outdoors, cut the shock cord and re assembled a pole to the length I wanted before re stringing it. I have the 1 man version & it‚Äôs surprisingly roomy with a big vestibule. I assume the 2 man will be plenty big enough. Condensation isn‚Äôt that bad for a single skin tent, venting is pretty good. I‚Äôve been out in terrible wind & rain and I stayed dry. The normal non pro Lanshan range are double skin if you‚Äôre worried about condensation but obviously weigh a bit more & don‚Äôt pack as tiny. They‚Äôre not free standing though so you need to be a bit more careful with the pitch but it‚Äôs worth it for the weight & pack size in my opinion.
data.author: Tim Williams

data.text: For a good budget option, check out the Lanshan 2 (not the pro) + a cheap set of aluminum 3 section hiking poles, in the price range of $120-$150
data.author: Toby Homsher

data.text: I'll check this out, thanks. The other person mentioned the lanshan pro, never even heard of it before. Time to look into them.

data.author: Erik Jansen

data.text: seriously, you‚Äôre going to hear about how great north face, big Agnes, marmot, and many high $$ tents. But it‚Äôs going to come down to your budget, preference, weight, space needed, etc. hence my recommendation is to find a reasonable price - REI, Kelty, and build from there. You won‚Äôt know what YOU want until you try some out, pack some on your bike. Good luck.
data.author: Gilbert Vargas

data.text: I recommend a tarp. Lighter and cheaper than a tent, as easy or easier to setup. You only need one object to string it up, your bike can always be the other end. If you can tie one knot you can setup a tarp faster than any tent. All the ultralight brands have great options. I can fit a tarp, ground sheet, sleeping bag, head net and a pillow all in handlebar bag that is much lighter than most. I chose a gossamer gear tarp. Other would work great as well.
data.author: Seth McFarland

data.text: I always look at tarp setups and wonder how do you deal with bugs and mosquitos? Maybe it isn't a problem in your place in the world.

data.text: I use Wild country Zephyros. Its made by Tera Nova. Light weight. Great little tent.
data.author: Harry Boe

data.text: A tarp is good, but if you get a really bad weather for a couple of days you‚Äôre going to need a tent, it doesn‚Äôt have to be the worlds best or most expensive, but it does need to be well built, light, big enough for you sit up in, there are lots of cheap tents, but they aren‚Äôt very big and the poles don‚Äôt last.
data.author: Fill Martini

data.text:
Naturehike tents are great, would recommend the cloud up 2. Have tried the single skin ones like the Taga but found it cold at night. You can get the 20D material 2person upgrade version on UK Amazon for ¬£169 at the moment but it was ¬£135 last week and even less from AliExpress. Naturehike Cloud-Up 2 Upgrade Camping Tent 2 Person 3-4 Season Lightweight Backpacking Tent https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07KPVL85V/

data.author: David Quashie

data.text: I would say it depends on your travel type and destination. Will you only bikepacking in warm climate or will you use your equipment also for other things or regions. I skipped my tarp because I often travel to Skandinavia and strong winds, a lot of rain sometimes and wide areas without trees or other adequate things to build a stable shelter are not so funny with a tarp.
data.author: Silvio Schl√∂ffel

data.text: MSR HUBA Free standing is definitely very handy at times
data.author: Chris Kelly

data.text: Location and weather probability are huge factors in deciding on a tent. Choose with that in mind.
data.author: P.W. Poubelle

data.text: it will all depend on the climate and terrain you will be traversing through. There is also the question of longevity and durability. If you are planning on relatively short trips in warm climates then go for a UL tent. If you are planning on longer trips where you need to have some durability choose a tent that offers that. If you are travelling in cold weather and high winds then you need a different tent that can handle that. I live and tour in Iceland, where the weather is cold and high windgusts are frequent and I made an investment in my tent as I plan to use it for hopefully the foreseeable future. My choice was a Hilleberg Soulo. A bombproof tent that keeps me warm, safe, dry and sheltered from the elements. It is also durable so I can count on being able to use it for a number of years. So even with the initial cost being high, then I hope that I do not have to make multiple tent purchases in the future. Many RTW travellers are choosing various Hilleberg models as their go to tents for their durability and how well built they are. Their drawback however is that they are not the lightest tents out there. My Soulo is 2,4kg, but again, its a 4 season tent. A 2person Hilleberg Allak which is a similar design as the Soulo is 3,3kg. Their lightest 2person models are 3season tents and their weights are around the 1,5kg mark. Their lightest solo tent is the Enan, which is 1,2kg. But again, its a 3season tent.
data.author: Andri Freyr Sigur√∞sson

data.text: I'm gonna take a look into this because the UL tents I see sometimes seem less durable which is a concern for me. Although I don't plan to go into extreme weather conditions intentionally
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Hilleberg Soulo is made for snow & ice blizzards. Especially the black label version (the red label is slightly lighter and cooler). Which model do you have? ...and how do you find it during the warmer months?
data.author: Daryl Knight

data.text: i have the red label. Warmest summer nights in iceland the temp hovers at about 12¬∞celsius. When the sun starts to shine the temp rises to just above 18. With some temp spikes above 25¬∞celsius. You feel it in the tent but its easy to vent. A bit of breeze helps. Those are the absolute highest temps I experience in the tent. Usually somewhere around 8-15¬∞ during daytime and 5-8¬∞ during night. But I know of several rtw cyclists who are using the soulo in every climate they face. If I was planning that then I would get the all inner mesh to change out the regular inner tent when I would get to much warmer climates.
data.author: Andri Freyr Sigur√∞sson

data.text: I've used ultralight tents and hilleberg tents. The hillebergs are amazing but could literally be used to cross the arctic. If that's not your plan, then any quality ultralight tent used properly will likely serve your needs perfectly well. And weigh and cost a fraction of the hilleberg. I am a fan of single-wall non-freestanding tents, personally.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: If it hasn't been mentioned already and you aren't after super ultra light, the NatureHike Mongar 2 is great (I have one, about 2kg). And I have seen good reviews of the Black Beer tent too (Another chineve brand, but at about 1.5kg) and I'm looking to maybe get one of those too. Both of those area WAY cheaper than the other brand names.
data.author: Aaron Koolen-Bourke

data.text: Hammock - lighter and no poles. Zpacks makes a great ultralight tent, but $$$$$. Or, carry a tarp and some rope - i use a Noah‚Äôs tarp by Kelty to camp sometimes.

data.text: Naturehike for sure! Love mine. Bikepacked all through south Island NZ in all sorts of weather including many downpours. Only downside, doesn't have a breathing part so condensation can build up a little. Way cheaper, been excellent. Cloud 2 I think I have?! Sorry bought it a while back. It's a small two man, Y shaped pole
data.author: Willy Ac

data.text: I use a Big Agnes Copper Spur. I didn't purchase it specifically for bikepacking. I already had it for backpacking and it works just fine for both.
data.author: Patty Cartwright

data.text: I had a Marmot 2p backpacking tent for years but have recently upgraded to the Big Agnes Copper Spur UL 2p bikepacking model. The shorter poles are what sells it for me, and going as small/light as I can with a tent (hammocks and tarps don‚Äôt work for me) is important, because I‚Äôm a small person with a small bike frame and bad joints. If you take excellent care of it, a good 3-season tent will last for years. The investment is worth the quality (and warranty).
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: Take a look at the Durston xmid pro. Durston designed this tent and it has received great reviews.

data.text:
Since you got a nice brand you bike, I‚Äôll check this awesome tent. Not cheap, but not the most expensive. It‚Äôs on sale. There‚Äôs 2 models from the Hotel. The Backpack Hotel (lighter, cheaper, longer poles to carry) and the Bikepack Hotel (heavier, more expensive, shorter poles to carry) Bikepacking model footprint is bigger and heavier too, and covers the main Hotel vestibule ground floor (not my favorite feature), where your bike, gear or cooking/chilling goes, instead of bare ground like the Hotel Backpacking model. Ymmv. Got this one yesterday in the mail. I‚Äôll test it soon and I‚Äôll let you know. I still have an MSR 3p Holler tent, but its main room, it‚Äôs so so big for only one person, and it‚Äôs more than 10yo. Seams flaked and I found some mildew inside the fly from storage. Not good. I set up the BA 2p Hotel tent inside home yesterday, and it‚Äôs roomy and the ‚Äúhotel‚Äù, the Hotel is good ü§© https://www.bigagnes.com/Blacktail-Hotel-2
Blacktail Hotel 2

data.author: Zan Cru

data.text: Buy once, cry once...won't regret a quality, light tent
data.author: Vincent Peragine

data.text: So I have the nemo dragonfly 2p bikepack tent which with the footprint is over $500 new. I got mine super lightly used on ebay for $200 and bought the footprint seperetaly. That was a lucky score. If I was going to go budget I'd get a hyke and byke tent they're about $100 new and do great in the rain and are trustworthy tents for their price. I have traveled with multiple people with this tent that reccomend it and I've seen them stay dry in heavy rain. I enjoy my nemo but generally wouldn't want to spend that much. I like the feature that it can strap to the bike and I use mine attached to my son's trailer this way. I haven't used mine in heavy rain yet so I am still anticipating that.
data.author: Suzie Roberts

data.text: Big Agnes Bikepacking tent (2-person). Worth the $$$. Lightweight & fits perfectly on my handlebars.

data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: yes and they are really nice. I sell them, and last summer a representative of Nordisk came to show me their tents. I put up one of naturehike to show him and he was really amazed by it. Nordisk has more bells and whistles, but the fabrics and poles are the same quality (and also Chinese, like everything nowadays) so he told me it would be difficult for me to sell these two brands next to eachother for the huge price difference for a to small quality difference in comparison.
